content:
Diagnosis:	Gallbladder adenocarcinoma, T4N1M1 with liver and lung metastases

Management:	15 Jan 2024 - Commenced gemcitabine/cisplatin
		12 Mar 2024 - Treatment break due to clinical deterioration

Histology:	Poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, HER2 equivocal (IHC 2+)

Current Situation:	Treatment break review

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with her daughter. Unfortunately, she has experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past three weeks, with worsening right upper quadrant pain, increasing fatigue, and reduced oral intake. Her performance status has declined from ECOG 1 to ECOG 3, now spending most of the day in bed. She describes persistent nausea despite regular ondansetron, and has lost a further 4kg since our last review.

Her most recent CT scan from 10/03/24 shows disease progression with increase in size of liver metastases (largest lesion now 8.2cm from 6.5cm) and new pulmonary nodules. Her liver function has also deteriorated with bilirubin rising to 45 μmol/L and albumin dropping to 28 g/L.

Given her significant clinical deterioration and radiological progression after two cycles of gemcitabine/cisplatin, we have had a detailed discussion about changing our approach to focus on symptom management. I have explained that further chemotherapy would carry significant risks with limited likelihood of benefit in her current condition. [redacted name] and her daughter understand this and agree with transitioning to best supportive care.

I have made an urgent referral to the palliative care team for review of her pain management and other symptoms. I have prescribed additional breakthrough analgesia and started dexamethasone 4mg daily to help with appetite and energy levels. We will continue to support her through our acute oncology service, and I have given direct contact details should any urgent issues arise. I have also arranged weekly district nurse input for support at home.

We will review her again in our supportive care clinic in one week's time to ensure appropriate symptom control is achieved. In the meantime, she has the acute oncology helpline number should she need urgent advice.
